metadata.title: Proofreading-deficient coronaviruses adapt over long-term passage for increased fidelity and 1 fitness without reversion of exoribonuclease-inactivating mutations 2 3 4

abstract.text: The coronavirus (CoV) RNA genome is the largest among single-stranded positive sense RNA 23 viruses. CoVs encode a proofreading 3¢à5¢exoribonuclease within nonstructural protein 14 24 (nsp14-ExoN) that is responsible for CoV high-fidelity replication. Alanine substitution of ExoN 25 catalytic residues [ExoN(-)] in SARS-CoV and murine hepatitis virus (MHV) disrupts ExoN 26 activity, yielding viable mutant viruses with defective replication, up to 20-fold decreased 27 fidelity, and increased susceptibility to nucleoside analogs. To test the stability of the ExoN(-) 28 genotype and phenotype, we passaged MHV-ExoN(-) 250 times in cultured cells (P250), in 29 parallel with WT-MHV. Compared to MHV-ExoN(-) P3, MHV-ExoN(-) P250 demonstrated 30 enhanced replication, reduced susceptibility to nucleoside analogs, and increased competitive 31 fitness. However, passage did not select for complete or partial reversion at the ExoN-32 inactivating mutations. We identified novel amino acid changes within the RNA-dependent RNA 33 polymerase (nsp12-RdRp) and nsp14 of MHV-ExoN(-) P250 that partially account for the 34 observed changes in replication, susceptibility to nucleoside analogs, and competitive fitness 35 observed in the passaged virus population, indicating that additional determinants can 36 compensate for the activities of nsp14-ExoN. Our results suggest that while selection favors 37 restoration of replication fidelity in ExoN(-) CoVs, there may be a significant barrier to ExoN(-) 38

reversion. These results also support the hypothesis that high-fidelity replication is linked to CoV 39 fitness and identify additional candidate proteins that may regulate CoV replication fidelity. 40 41 42 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

body_text.text: 9 also deleted ORF 4a, which is dispensable for MHV replication in cell culture (52). The C-150 terminal region of ns2 within MHV-ExoN(-) P250 was truncated and fused to HE with a -1 151 frameshift. Ns2 is a phosphodiesterase (PDE) that protects viral RNA by degrading 2¢à5¢ 152 oligoadenylate, the activating factor for cellular RNase L (53-55). The portion of ns2 deleted in The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/175562 doi: bioRxiv preprint similar for all four viruses (Fig. 4B) . These data suggest that the increased replication of P250 173 viruses relative to WT-MHV is not fully accounted for by increased RNA synthesis. In addition 174 to RNA synthesis defects, ExoN(-) CoVs have up-to 20-fold increased mutation frequencies and 175 profoundly increased sensitivity to nucleoside and base analogs relative to WT CoVs (13, 14, 16, 176 17, 38). To determine whether nucleoside analog sensitivity of MHV-ExoN(-) was altered by 177 long-term passage, we treated cells infected with parental and passaged viruses with the base 178 analog, 5-fluorouracil (5-FU). 5-FU is converted intracellularly into a nucleoside analog that 179 incorporates into growing RNA strands and causes A:G and U:C mutations. For simplicity, we 180 hereafter refer to 5-FU as a nucleoside analog. Incorporation of 5-FU is increased in the absence 181 of ExoN activity (16). All viruses displayed a concentration-dependent decrease in viral titer but 182 differed greatly in their susceptibility to 5-FU (Fig. 4C ). At 120µM, WT-MHV P3 titers were 183 reduced by ~1 log 10 , while MHV-ExoN(-) P3 titers were undetectable (> 5 log 10 -fold reduction). 184

WT-MHV 5-FU sensitivity was not altered by passage. MHV-ExoN(-) P250 was less susceptible 185 than MHV-ExoN(-) P3 to 5-FU treatment, with only a ~1.5 log 10 decrease in titer at 120 µM. replication cycles in which 5-FU can be incorporated (59) . MHV-ExoN(-) P250 had multiple 193 mutations in the spike glycoprotein, including one in the spike furin cleavage site that reduced 194 syncytia formation. To test whether the spike mutations manifested in resistance to 5-FU, we 195 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

were identified in the ExoN domain, and 2 NS mutations were in the C-terminal N7-216 methyltransferase domain (Fig. 6B ). We next modeled the structure of MHV nsp14 using Phyre 2 217 software (63) , resulting in highest-probability similarity to the SARS-CoV nsp14-nsp10 complex 218 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/175562 doi: bioRxiv preprint between the structures) of 100% for residues 3-519 of MHV-nsp14. The model predicts that five 220 mutations are located close to surface of the protein (Fig. 6B ). All three modeled zinc finger 221 domains contain one NS mutation (F216Y, Y248H, L473I). Two mutations, D128E and F216Y, 222 are located near the interface between nsp10 and nsp14, though neither site has previously been 223 implicated in nsp10-nsp14 interaction (15, 64, 65). One NS mutation resulted in a D272E 224 substitution in ExoN motif III, a metal-coordinating active site residue. We previously reported 225 that alanine substitution of D272 results in an ExoN(-) phenotype (14), but the viability or 226 phenotype of a D272E substitution was not tested in that study. These data suggest that a 227 network of residues evolved to regulate nsp12 and nsp14 activity or stability in the ExoN(-) 228 background. 229 230 Fixed mutations in nsp12 and nsp14 in MHV-ExoN(-) P250 directly correlate with 231 increased resistance to multiple nucleoside analogs. To determine approximately when the 232 mutations in nsp12 and nsp14 arose, we performed di-deoxy sequencing across these protein-233 coding regions roughly every 20 passages (P10, 31, 50, 72, 90, 100, 120, 140, 160, 180, 200, 220, 234 240) . By this method, we detected consensus NS mutations at P10, P50, and P160 for nsp12, and 235 at P50 and P160 for nsp14 (Fig. 6) . Both nsp12 and nsp14 carried their full complement of P250 236 consensus mutations by P160, except for a minority variant (D913E) in nsp12 maintained at 237 <50% of the population between P200 and P250. These passage levels correlated with increased 238 replication of MHV-ExoN(-) (Fig. 2B ) and with decreasing sensitivity to 5-FU (Fig. 7A ). Neither 239 replication nor 5-FU sensitivity of MHV-ExoN(-) changed substantially between P160 and P250. 240
To determine whether MHV-ExoN(-) evolved increased resistance to multiple nucleoside 241 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF0.text: 153 MHV-ExoN(-) P250 lies outside the PDE catalytic domain, in a region of unknown function. C-154 terminally truncated ns2 retains enzymatic activity (56), but whether this specific deletion and 155 fusion disrupts PDE activity remains to be tested. Nevertheless, ns2 is dispensable for MHV 156 replication in immortalized cells (57, 58). Details about the deletion sites are provided in 157 Supplemental Figure 1. Within proteins predicted to be part of the replicase-transcriptase 158 complex (nsp7-16 and nucleocapsid) (39), WT-MHV P250 had only one NS change, located in 159 the nsp13-helicase (Fig. 3A). In contrast, MHV-ExoN(-) P250 had 17 NS changes within this 160 region (Fig. 3B and Supplemental Tables 1, 2). 161 162 MHV-ExoN(-) P250 displays increased genomic RNA accumulation and increased 163 resistance to 5-fluorouracil. Coronaviruses lacking ExoN consistently display defects in RNA 164 synthesis relative to WT (14, 16, 43). To determine whether the increased replication of MHV-165 ExoN(-) P250 was associated with restored genomic RNA (gRNA) production, we measured 166 gRNA accumulation over time using two-step real-time quantitative PCR (15, 16). MHV-ExoN(-167 ) P250 accumulated similar levels of gRNA to WT-MHV P3 and WT-MHV P250 at early time 168 points, while gRNA levels for MHV-ExoN(-) P3 were ~1 log 10 lower (Fig. 4A). MHV-ExoN(-) 169 P250 gRNA levels fell below those of WT-MHV and WT-MHV P250 after 8 hours and were 170 similar to those of MHV-ExoN(-) P3 at 10 hours post-infection. Normalizing to the gRNA 171 abundance at four hours for each virus demonstrated that the rates of gRNA accumulation were 172 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF1.text: 186 MHV-ExoN(-) P250 remained more sensitive to 5-FU than WT-MHV, suggesting that WT-like 187 resistance requires an intact ExoN. These data demonstrate that MHV-ExoN(-) P3 evolved 188 resistance to 5-FU through mutations outside of ExoN(-) motif I. 189 190 Spike mutations in MHV-ExoN(-) P250 do not increase resistance to 5-FU. Bacteriophage 191 ϕX174 acquired resistance to 5-FU by delaying cell lysis, thereby reducing the number of 192

FIGREF2.text: of viral particles(Fig. 5B). However, the MHV-ExoN(-) P250 spike did not 199 affect sensitivity of the recombinant virus to 5-FU(Fig. 5C). Thus, any adaptive increase in 5-FU 200 resistance must be located elsewhere in the genome.201 202 MHV-ExoN(-) passage resulted in unique mutations in nsp12 and nsp14. To date, three 203 proteins have been shown to alter CoV sensitivity to 5-FU: the nsp12-RdRp, nsp14-ExoN, and 204 nsp10, which stimulates ExoN activity (15, 17, 39). Neither WT-MHV nor MHV-ExoN(-) P250 205 contained a NS mutation in nsp10, and WT-MHV P250 had no mutations within either nsp12 or 206 nsp14. In contrast, MHV-ExoN(-) P250 had 7 NS mutations in nsp12 and 6 NS mutations in 207 nsp14 (Figs. 3, 6), none of which have been described previously in vitro or in viable viruses. 208 Within nsp12, six mutations were in the predicted RdRp fingers, palm, and thumb domains (Fig. 209 6A) (60). Four residues (H709, F766, S776, and M814) can be visualized on a Phyre 2 -modeled 210 structure of the MHV-nsp12 RdRp, while the remainder lie outside the modeled core RdRp (Fig. 211 6A) (17). One mutation, M288T, lies in the CoV-specific domain, which is conserved among 212 nidoviruses. This domain has been implicated in membrane targeting in MHV-A59 (61) and 213 performs an essential nucleotidylation activity in the arterivirus, equine arteritis virus (62). 214

FIGREF3.text: AZC), an RNA mutagen (67); and 2'-C-methyladenosine (CMeA), which is proposed to 245 incorporate in viral RNA and terminate nascent transcripts (68). As with 5-FU, we observed 246 dose-dependent sensitivity to RBV, AZC, and CMeA in all MHV-ExoN(-) viruses that decreased 247 with increasing passage number (Fig. 7B-D). Except against AZC, MHV-ExoN(-) sensitivity did 248 not change between P160 and P250. Together, these data demonstrate that MHV-ExoN(-) 249 evolved increased resistance to multiple nucleoside analogs that correlated with the length of 250 passage and the acquisition of mutations in nsp12 and nsp14. Importantly, this occurred in the 251 absence of specific mutagenic selection and without reversion of ExoN motif I. This increased 252 general selectivity towards all four classes of nucleotide strongly advocates for an overall 253 increase in fidelity in MHV-ExoN(-) P250. 254 255 Mutations in nsp12 partially account for increased resistance of MHV-ExoN(-) P250 to 256 multiple nucleoside analogs. We hypothesized that mutations in MHV-ExoN(-) P250 nsp12 and 257 nsp14 were most likely to impact replication and nucleoside analog sensitivity based on their 258 enzymatic activities and temporal association with phenotypic changes. To test this hypothesis, 259 we engineered recombinant MHV-ExoN(-) to encode the P250 nsp12 and nsp14, alone and 260together. Expression of nsp12-P250 and nsp14-P250, alone or in combination, altered replication 261 kinetics of MHV-ExoN(-) without affecting peak titers(Fig. 8A) and increased gRNA levels 262 above those of MHV-ExoN(-) P3(Fig. 8B). Nsp12-P250 had a greater effect than nsp14-P250 on 263 the sensitivity of MHV-ExoN(-) to all analogs tested, and the combination of nsp12-and nsp14-264 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF4.text: of MHV-ExoN(-) P250, and that adaptations in nsp12-P250 mask those in 268 nsp14-P250. We also can conclude that the nsp14-P250 D272E active site mutation does not 269 correct the defect caused by the motif I DEàAA substitutions. Together, the results suggest 270 possible limitations for fidelity adaptation in nsp12 and nsp14, and also the exciting prospect that 271 other CoV proteins participate in fidelity regulation within MHV-ExoN(-) P250. 272 273 Resistance to nucleoside analogs correlates with MHV-ExoN(-) fitness. We hypothesized that 274 mutations in nsp12 and nsp14 provided a fitness advantage to MHV-ExoN(-) P250. We 275 competed the recombinant viruses with a reference MHV-ExoN(-) virus (P1 stock) containing 10 276 silent mutations in the nsp2 coding region. Mutant and reference viruses were detected in the 277 mixed infection by real-time quantitative PCR using dual-labeled probes specific for each virus. 278 MHV-ExoN(-) P3 showed a modest fitness advantage over the reference P1 MHV-ExoN(-) 279 silent (Fig. 8F, solid green). MHV-ExoN(-) P250 profoundly outcompeted MHV-ExoN(-) silent, 280 with >1000-fold more MHV-ExoN(-) P250 genomes present at the end of passage 1 (Fig. 8F, 281 dotted green). MHV-ExoN(-) nsp12-P250 had greater relative fitness than MHV-ExoN(-) nsp14-282 P250, and MHV-ExoN(-) nsp12/14-P250 was intermediate between the single recombinants, 283

FIGREF5.text: fitness, nucleoside analog resistance, and virulence (16, 17, 38). Yet no direct test 293 of the requirement for ExoN activity for long-term survival and stability of the CoV genome had 294 been performed. In this study, we describe experimental adaptive evolution of WT-MHV and 295 MHV-ExoN(-) during long-term passage in cell culture. WT-MHV evolved increased replication 296 kinetics over 250 passages, with few consensus mutations arising in the WT-MHV P250 genome. 297 In contrast, MHV-ExoN(-) accumulated 8-fold more mutations than WT-MHV, none of which 298 occurred at the ExoN-inactivating mutations. Nevertheless, MHV-ExoN(-) P250 demonstrated 299 increased replication kinetics and increased resistance to nucleoside analogs as compared to 300 MHV-ExoN(-) P3. Mutations within nsp12-P250 conferred greater resistance to nucleoside 301 analogs than nsp14-P250, suggesting that secondary mutations within nsp14 cannot restore ExoN 302 activity without the full complement of catalytic DE-E-D residues. These results further support 303 our studies and those from other exonucleases that the motif I DE residues are absolutely 304 required for ExoN activity. However, mutations in nsp12-P250 also were not sufficient, alone or 305 in combination with nsp14-P250, to account for the increased nucleoside analog resistance of the 306 MHV-ExoN(-) P250 virus population, indicating that other proteins contribute to resistance or 307 that the virus evolved increased mutational robustness over passage. 308 309 Why doesn't MHV-ExoN(-) revert over long-term passage? We detected no primary 310 reversion at the DEàAA substitutions MHV-ExoN(-) at any passage tested. These data are 311 consistent with and significantly extend previous studies reporting genotypic stability of ExoN(-) 312 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF6.text: would require four nucleotide changes. This likely represents a high genetic barrier to 314 reversion, especially given that fitness can be increased by mutations outside of nsp14-ExoN. 315Single and double nucleotide changes within motif I could restore acidic charge to individual 316 residues (e.g. motif I EA, AD, ED, etc). However, the active site compositions of DEDDh 317 exonucleases, such as the Klenow fragment, are so stringent that even conservative mutations 318(D-to-E or E-to-D) reduce ExoN activity by >96% (70). Thus, intermediate amino acid changes 319 may not have a selective advantage compared to motif I AA, limiting the evolutionary pathways 320 to reversion. However, nsp14-P250 increased competitive fitness in the MHV-ExoN(-) 321 background (Fig. 8F), demonstrating a modest capacity for fitness adaptation in nsp14 outside of 322 the catalytic residues. Whether these mutations resulted from genetic drift or positive selection 323 remains unclear. Nevertheless, our data show that MHV-ExoN(-) can adapt for increased fitness 324 without fully restoring exoribonuclease activity. Understanding the mechanisms by which MHV-325 ExoN(-) P250 compensated for ExoN activity could allow recovery of ExoN(-) variants of other 326 CoVs, such as transmissible gastroenteritis virus and human CoV 229E, which to date have been 327 unrecoverable as ExoN(-) recombinants (43, 71). 328 329 CoV adaptation to loss of ExoN-mediated proofreading. High-fidelity replication, made 330 possible in part by the proofreading activity of nsp14-ExoN, is thought to have been essential for 331 the expansion and maintenance of large CoV genomes (39, 40, 69). Compensation for the loss of 332 ExoN could have occurred through the evolution of increased fidelity via other replicase proteins. 333

FIGREF7.text: polymerase fidelity. First, nonsynonymous mutations to the RdRp arose in the 336 low-fidelity MHV-ExoN(-) but not in the presence of proofreading (WT-MHV). Second, five of 337 the mutations lie in or near structural motifs important for fidelity regulation in other RdRps. 338 Amino acid substitutions in the fingers and palm domains have been repeatedly shown to affect 339 viral RdRp fidelity (25, 34), and we have recently reported a fingers mutation (nsp12-V553I) that 340 likely increases the fidelity of the MHV RdRp (17). Our modeled structure predicts that nsp12-341 P250 contains three mutations in the palm domain and one in the fingers domain, with the 342 M814K thumb domain mutation lying near the palm (Fig. 6A). Third, exchange of nsp12-P250 343 alone into the background of MHV-ExoN(-) reduced the susceptibility of MHV-ExoN(-) to three 344 different nucleoside analogs (Fig. 8). Although resistance to a single nucleoside analog can 345 evolve without increasing overall fidelity, resistance to multiple nucleoside analogs suggests a 346 broadly increased capacity to discriminate modified nucleotides {Arias:2008bp, Sierra:2007dg, 347 Zeng:2013dg, Guo:2016fx}. Thus, nsp12-P250 is likely a high-fidelity polymerase. However, 348 nsp12-P250 only partially accounts for the MHV-ExoN(-) P250 nucleoside analog resistance 349 phenotype (Fig. 8), suggesting a possible limit to the compensation achievable by mutating the 350 RdRp alone. Further, the effects of mutations in nsp12-P250 and nsp14-P250 are not additive 351 and may be antagonistic when isolated from the whole passaged virus (Fig. 8), indicating that the 352 relationships between nsp12-and nsp14-P250 mutations are likely evolutionarily linked with 353 those in other MHV proteins. In fact, a substantial component of the evolved resistance to 354 nucleoside analogs cannot be explained by nsp12-P250 and nsp14-P250, alone or together. In 355 support of this hypothesis, we identified several nonsynonymous mutations in other replicase 356 proteins, such as nsps 8, 9, 13, and 15. SARS-CoV nsp8 and nsp13 have functional interactions 357

FIGREF8.text: chikungunya virus and foot-and-mouth disease virus can evolve to increase fidelity 361 (79) and alter the frequency of ribavirin-induced mutations(80), respectively. SARS-CoV nsp9 362 has RNA-binding activities and is proposed to participate in the multi-protein replicase complex 363 (39, 81), and MHV nsp15 is a uridylate-specific endoribonuclease (82). Both could plausibly be 364 involved in modifying polymerase activity. Additionally, it remains possible that evolution for 365 increased fidelity could involve proteins outside the canonical replication complex (nsps7-16), 366 including those in the structural and accessory cassette. Thus, while immediate studies will focus 367 on testing whether replicase proteins nsp8, 9, 13, and 15 regulate fidelity, it is exciting to 368 consider the possibility that this virus-directed discovery approach will reveal novel interactions 369 between multiple MHV proteins.370 371 Has MHV-ExoN(-) P250 evolved robustness as a defense against ExoN(-) infidelity? Three 372 of the nucleoside analogs used in this study (5-FU, ribavirin, and 5-azacytidine) reduce virus 373 titers at least in part through mutagenesis (16, 66, 67). Although the resistance of MHV-ExoN(-) 374 P250 to these RNA mutagens may be fully explained by the evolution of a high-fidelity 375 replication complex, an additional possibility is that MHV-ExoN(-) P3 evolved increased 376 mutational robustness. Mutational robustness is the capacity of a virus to buffer the fitness 377 effects of mutations, which are most frequently detrimental or lethal (8-12). Thus, in a low-378 fidelity virus like MHV-ExoN(-) P3, genomic mutations which reduce the fitness cost of 379 subsequent mutations can provide a selective advantage (83-85). The relationship between 380 fidelity and robustness has been demonstrated for poliovirus and coxsackievirus B3: wild-type 381 ExoN(-) P250. Synonymous changes can alter codons to reduce the probability of non-384 conservative amino acid changes (87). Alternatively, the increased population size of MHV-385 ExoN(-) P250 could promote robustness by a "safety-in-numbers" effect, allowing efficient 386 purging of low-fitness mutants while maintaining population fitness (88). Large populations also 387 increase the likelihood of co-infection, allowing complementation between viral genomes. We 388 did not observe an effect of increased replication in MHV-ExoN(-) P250 nucleoside analog 389 resistance (Fig. 5), but a recent study with poliovirus suggests that mutagenized populations have 390 elevated coinfection frequencies (89). Thus, complementation may contribute to MHV-ExoN(-) 391 P250 nucleoside analog resistance. Conflicting evidence exists regarding whether mutational 392 robustness itself affects the sensitivity to RNA mutagens (86, 87, 90); nevertheless, the 393 robustness of MHV-ExoN(-) P250 merits further investigation. 394 395Conclusions. One of the defining features of CoV replication is the proofreading activity of the 396 nsp14 exoribonuclease that is a critical determinant of CoV replication, fidelity, and fitness. We 397 here show that CoVs also have the capacity to compensate for loss of ExoN activity through a 398 network of mutations in nsp12, nsp14, and elsewhere in the genome. Thus, while nsp14-ExoN 399 appears to play a dominant role in CoV replication fidelity, its activity is likely closely tied to a 400 highly evolved network of proteins. The demonstrated co-adaptation for replication, fidelity, and 401 competitive fitness within MHV-ExoN(-) supports the hypothesis that these roles are linked 402 functionally and evolutionarily. Genetic and biochemical testing of the rich mutational resource 403 revealed in MHV-ExoN(-) P250 will likely inform the design of countermeasures for endemic 404 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF9.text: -term passage of virus and stock generation. The infectious cDNA clone for MHV-A59 414 and the recovery of MHV-ExoN(-) are described previously (14, 91). Long-term passage was 415 initiated by infecting subconfluent monolayers of DBT-9 cells in 25 cm 2 flasks with either wild-416 type MHV-A59 or MHV-ExoN(-) at a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of approximately 0.1 417 particle forming unit per cell (PFU/cell). One lineage of each virus was passaged blindly for a 418 total of 250 passages (P250). Supernatant was harvested at each passage and stored at -80°C. 419 Total RNA was harvested for most passages using 1 ml of TRIzol Reagent (Ambion) per 25 cm 2 420 flask and stored at -80°C. Virus stocks of select intermediate passages were generated by 421 infecting a subconfluent 150 cm 2 flask of DBT-9 cells at an MOI of 0.01 PFU/cell. 422 Approximately 24 hours post-infection the flask was frozen at -80°C and the supernatant was 423 clarified by centrifugation at 4,000 x g (Sorvall RC 3B Plus; HA-6000A rotor) for 10 min at 4°C. 424

FIGREF10.text: Sequencing of virus stocks. Following P250, RNA was purified from the harvested TRIzol 435 samples according to the manufacturer's protocol and reverse transcribed (RT) using SuperScript 436 III (Invitrogen) as described previously (14). Full-genome di-deoxy sequencing was performed 437 for both WT-MHV P250 and MHV-ExoN(-) P250 using 12 overlapping amplicons 438 approximately three kilobases in length. All coding regions were sequenced fully, and out of 439 31,409 nucleotides, > 99% were sequenced for each virus [WT-MHV P250: 21-31,279 and 440 MHV-ExoN(-) P250: 21-31,275]. Two microliters of RT product were used for each PCR 441 reaction (16). Di-deoxy sequencing was performed by Genhunter Corporation (Nashville, TN) or 442 GENEWIZ (South Plainfield, NJ). Sequence analysis was performed using MacVector version 443 14 (MacVector, Inc.; Apex, North Carolina) using the MHV-A59 infectious clone reference 444 genome (GenBank accession no. AY910861). The nucleotide sequences of the amplicon and 445 sequencing primers are available upon request. Sequencing of nsp12 and nsp14 from 446 intermediate passages was performed using TRIzol-purified RNA from infected monolayers and 447 using the primers listed below. Primers 6M1F (5'-TTTTGGCGAGATGGTAGC-3'nsp14. RNA was reverse-transcribed using 460 SuperScript III (Invitrogen), and cDNA derived from intracellular positive-sense viral RNA was 461 measured using primers directed to nsp10. Values were normalized to levels of the endogenous 462 control glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH). No mutations within the primer 463 binding sites emerged in either P250 population. The primers and amplification conditions are 464 the same as reported previously (15), except that the RT product was diluted 1:10 prior to use. 465 Samples were plated in technical duplicate to minimize well-to-well variation. The levels of genomic RNA in supernatant were measured using one-step 471 real-time quantitative RT-PCR (RT-qPCR) on TRIzol-extracted RNA as described previously 472 (17). Briefly, genomic RNA was detected with a 5' 6-carboxyfluorescein (FAM) and 3' black 473 hole quencher 1 (BHQ-1) labeled probe targeting nsp2 (Biosearch Technologies, Petaluma, CA), 474
